column10: Northern Puget Sound: Samish Bay, Bellingham Bay, Lummi Bay, Drayton Harbor, Fidalgo Bay, Padilla Bay
column18: SF Bay North Bay/San Pablo Bay (north of Richmond Bridge)
column19: SF Bay Richardson Bay, excluding Sausalito
column24: Long Beach Harbor- Terminal Island area

column2: Is recruitment limited in the estuary?
column4: Aquaculture has potential to make biggest positive difference in estuaries with low recruitment
column6: Recruitment is generally high in this estuary
column7: Some sites or years have recruitment failure

column2: Is Olympia oyster population in estuary at risk of local extinction?
column4: Aquaculture has the potential to make the biggist positive difference in estuaries with very low adult populations
column6: Adult population stable; likelihood of local extinction very low
column7: Adult population declining but not at immediately risk of local extinction
column8: Adult population declining strongly or entirely absent; at high risk of local extinction from this estuary

column4: Places with high post-recruitment survival should be prioritized, and/or mortality addressed before aquaculture techniques are implemented. (Not worth investing in aquaculture if most oysters will die from drill predation, freshwater event, etc.)
column6: Juveniles and adults have low survival rate (<20% of 10mm+ oysters survive 1 year)
column7: Juveniles and adults have medium survival rates (<50% of oysters survive 1 year)
column8: Juveniles and adults have high survival rates (>50% of oysters survive 1 year)

column2: How isolated are populations in this area?
column4: Estuaries or areas that are isolated and do not have larval exchange from nearby populations are more vulnerable to a potential loss of an entire population, and may benefit more from conservation aquaculture as a tool
column6: Not isolated at all (substantial Oly populations within 20 km along coastline from this area; OR based on currents or genetics, evidence that this population is quite connected to nearby populations)
column7: Moderately isolated (substantial Oly population between 20-100 km along coastline from this area; OR based on currents or genetics, evidence that this population has some connectivity to nearby populations
column8: Very isolated (no substantial (>10,000 individuals) Oly population within 100 km along coastline from this area; OR based on currents or genetics, evidence that this is a largely closed population)

column2: Is there a nearby COMMERCIAL hatchery that can cost-effectively produce spat from local broodstock?
column4: A commercial hatchery is in the same estuary, to reduce shipping costs and risk of introducing disease etc., and to maximize output of spat for restoration (see Ted's draft list on READ ME tab)
column6: Hatchery that can cost-effectively produce millions of single Olys located >100 km away from estuary
column7: Hatchery located <100 km away, but not on same estuary

column2: Is there a nearby RESTORATION hatchery that can produce spat from local broodstock?
column4: A small scale hatchery (e.g. a marine lab, university)  in the same estuary that can produce restoration-only sized batches of spat, to reduce shipping costs and risk of introducing disease etc.  This may also minimize risks associated with commercial production such as hatchery-driven selection, but the volume of spat produced will be lower.  (see Ted's draft list on READ ME tab)
column6: Hatchery that can cost-effectively produce thousands of Olys located >100 km away from estuary
column7: Hatchery located <100 km away, but not on same estuary

column2: Is it safe to eat shellfish?
column4: Areas where water quality allows for safe consumption of Olys can be used for commercial production or community harvesting.  Any area where consumption of Olys would endanger human health will be excluded from consideration for commercial production or community harvest (though not from restoration).
column5: Commercial growers; Tribes and other communities interested in harvest
column6: Chronic unsafe conditions for shellfish consumption due to high E. coli, pesticides, etc.
column7: Occasional unsafe conditions for shellfish consumption, e.g. due to red tides (Harmful Algal Blooms)
column8: Generally safe conditions for shellfish consumption

column4: Areas where harvest is allowed should be prioritized for community groups interested in harvest and commercial growers.  Areas where harvest is not allowed can still be used for restoration.
column5: Commercial growers; Tribes and other communities interested in harvest
column7: Harvest allowed but certain areas of the estuary are resticted even within areas where oysters grow
column8: Harvest allowed anywhere in the estuary (where oysters grow)

column2: Is post-settlement growth high, med or low?
column4: Sites with higher growth rates could be prioritized for areas of harvesting of oysters and commercial aquaculture; challenges to low growth rates should be ameliorated if possible before aquaculture techniques are implemented
column5: Commercial growers; Tribes and other communities interested in harvest
column6: Growth is slower than average for the species

column2: Are Olympia oysters or any other species of bivalves currently being farmed in this estuary?
column4: If the infrastructure exists for farming bivalves, Olympia oysters could more easily be integrated, and precedents have been set for farming bivalves (water quality, harvest, etc.) (see Ted's draft list on READ ME tab)
column5: Commercial growers; Tribes and other communities interested in harvest

column2: Is Olympia oyster restoration/enhancement part of the management plan/conservation plan of an agency (state or federal), NGO, Native American Tribe, or other organization in this estuary?
column4: Location and capacity of partners to lead restoration projects where permiting allows aquaculture.  Higher score will increase the chances of successful implementation of projects and future follow-through/investment by NGOs.

column2: Are there community or volunteer groups currently engaged in Olympia oyster restoration?
column4: Aquaculture-based restoration is likely to succeed and positively affect people where there are engaged communities

column2: Are other community groups currently engaged in other species of bivalve/shellfish restoration?
column4: Existing capacity for volunteers engaged in restoration with similar species could indicate a capacity for/interest in incorporating Olympia oyster restoration in the future
column5: Conservation planners, Tribes and other communities interested in harvest

column2: Are there Tribes and First Nations currently engaged in bivalve/shellfish restoration or wild harvest?
column4: Tribal / First Nations communities are engaged in efforts to restore beds for future harvest, cultural importance, and/or conservation, either because they historically harvested native oysters and/or incorporated this species into their cultural practices. Tribal stewardship increases the chances of successful and long-term restoration and management of oyster populations.
column6: No Tribes / First Nations engaged in shellfish restoration or aquaculture
column7: 1 or more Tribes / First Nationsengaged in shellfish retstoration or aquaculture
column8: 1 or more Tribes / First Nations engaged in oyster restoration/aquaculture

column2: Are other community groups currently engaged in oyster/bivalve/shellfish culture for harvest (non-commercial groups)?
column4: Communities that harvest bivalves, including oysters, can increase the success of restoration efforts via the stewardship, maintenance and management of oyster beds

column2: Are there known risks to the production of Crassostrea or other species of aquacultured oysters?
column4: If this estuary has known threats (e.g. acidification, disease), then Olys may diversify portfolio
column6: No major problems to date with Crassostrea production related to acidification or disease
column7: Some issues with Crassostrea that might not affect Olys (acidification, disease, etc.)
column8: Extensive problems with Crassostrea production from threats might apply less to Olys
column9: NA if no aquaculture in estuary
